Adds a workflow engine (via ruote) to your Ruby application, with tools for task authorization and locking.

commit_list.message:
Only use brute force process kill when :force true

Just clearing the storage (or removing all of a process's messages) can
result in the worker losing its mind, if a worker is running and trying
to process messages, trackers, etc while the storage is emptied.  If you
know it's safe to do so, you can add :force => true to the .kill_process
and .kill_all_processes methods.
commit_list.repo_description: Adds a workflow engine (via ruote) to your Ruby application, with tools for task authorization and locking.
Adds a workflow engine (via ruote) to your Ruby application, with tools for task authorization and locking.

commit_list.repo_description: Adds a workflow engine (via ruote) to your Ruby application, with tools for task authorization and locking.
Adds a workflow engine (via ruote) to your Ruby application, with tools for task authorization and locking.

commit_list.message:
More flexible configuration and bootstrapping

The process for initializing Bumbleworks has been more clearly
separated from bootstrapping the process definitions and participant
registration list, and both activities are now cleaned up
considerably.  Notably, none of the directories are required anymore;
if a default path doesn't exist, its associated behavior is a no-op.
For example, if no participant directory exists, no autoloading of
participants will occur.
commit_list.repo_description: Adds a workflow engine (via ruote) to your Ruby application, with tools for task authorization and locking.

Adds a workflow engine (via ruote) to your Ruby application, with tools for task authorization and locking.

commit_list.message:
Change root discovery and default directory logic

It used to be that the default directories included the assumed lib
path (lib/bumbleworks), which meant that the default Bumbleworks.root
was the base app directory.  This made it difficult to set the root
directory somewhere else without either replicating the lib/bumbleworks
hierarchy (for tasks, participants, and processes directories), or
explicitly setting those paths in config as well.  Now, the default root
itself includes lib/bumbleworks (appended to the framework's app root),
which makes it much easier to relocate your BW directories.
commit_list.repo_description: Adds a workflow engine (via ruote) to your Ruby application, with tools for task authorization and locking.
Adds a workflow engine (via ruote) to your Ruby application, with tools for task authorization and locking.

commit_list.message:
Optionally leave PIDs alone when cancelling all

When cancelling all processes on an Bumbleworks::Entity, by default all
process identifiers are cleared (by persisting nil to them).  This is
undesirable if the entity update a) leads to side effects or b) is
performed when the entity is being destroyed anyway.  Now you can send
a :clear_identifiers option to cancel_all_processes! - it defaults to
true, but if you explicitly set it to false, the pids will be left
alone.
commit_list.repo_description: Adds a workflow engine (via ruote) to your Ruby application, with tools for task authorization and locking.
Adds a workflow engine (via ruote) to your Ruby application, with tools for task authorization and locking.

commit_list.message:
Specify extra fields/variables on process launch

Now, when calling #launch_process on a Bumbleworks::Entity, you can
specify additional fields and variables to be sent to the launch
method - these will be merged with the return values from process_fields
and process_variables.  Also, refactored the entity module, mostly
insignificant, but the important change is that :column is replaced with
:attribute, so if you override the persistence attribute, use that key
instead.  This is done to reflect a lack of dependency on any specific
form of persistence.
commit_list.repo_description: Adds a workflow engine (via ruote) to your Ruby application, with tools for task authorization and locking.

commit_list.message:
Task finder - add with_fields and #where shortcut

Using Task::Finder#where lets you specify several options in the same
method call - this is just a shortcut and does the same thing as
chaining the specified methods.  In fact, it can be combined with method
chaining.  The #completable query also gained an inverse option (send
false as an argument).
commit_list.repo_description: Adds a workflow engine (via ruote) to your Ruby application, with tools for task authorization and locking.

commit_list.message:
Add entity lookup to Bumbleworks::Process

This is a little trickier than Task or Participant entity lookup, since
a running process may have multiple workitems (in multiple active
leaves of the workflow).  The design here is that if all leaves agree
on which entity is represented, that entity will be returned - otherwise
an EntityConflict exception will be raised.
commit_list.repo_description: Adds a workflow engine (via ruote) to your Ruby application, with tools for task authorization and locking.

commit_list.message:
Move entity store methods into new Workitem class

WorkitemEntityStorage now delegates to a Bumbleworks::Workitem instance
created using the including object's workitem.  This also allows us to
explicitly ask a workitem for its perceived entity, which comes in
handy when we need entity queries on flow expressions... also, change
Furby to RainbowLoom to stay hip.
commit_list.repo_description: Adds a workflow engine (via ruote) to your Ruby application, with tools for task authorization and locking.
Adds a workflow engine (via ruote) to your Ruby application, with tools for task authorization and locking.

commit_list.message:
Resimplify Participant classes, more renames

Keep the participants in their own directory; that was a good idea.  The
reorg, not so much.  Going back to the simpler hierarchy, but the
error handler participant has been renamed to the ErrorDispatcher to
better differentiate it from the ErrorHandler interface class
(implementations of which are *subscribers* to the dispatcher).
commit_list.repo_description: Adds a workflow engine (via ruote) to your Ruby application, with tools for task authorization and locking.
Adds a workflow engine (via ruote) to your Ruby application, with tools for task authorization and locking.

commit_list.message:
Introducing the EntityInteractor participant!

The entity interactor lets you call methods on the process's entity,
with or without arguments, and optionally store the return value in
a workitem field.
commit_list.repo_description: Adds a workflow engine (via ruote) to your Ruby application, with tools for task authorization and locking.

commit_list.message:
Overhaul of "participant" file/class hierarchy

Renamed a bunch of core components, so this will break existing
implementations - good thing we're not even at 0.1.x, yet, for some
reason.

commit_list.message:
Process#process_status, method missing delegation

Our process class semantically represents an
actual process instance (and can thus be "killed"
and "cancelled", etc.), but we can benefit from
a lot of the methods on Ruote::ProcessStatus.
commit_list.repo_description: Adds a workflow engine (via ruote) to your Ruby application, with tools for task authorization and locking.

commit_list.message:
Task::Finder#completable and #available

This finally adds post-instantiation filtering to
Task::Finder; previously, all queries were done on
the raw workitem hash (not even the workitem
instance).  Now we can have a mix of filters -
#completable will be applied after the tasks are
instantiated, but can be in the chain in any
order.  #available is just a shortcut to get
#unclaimed and #completable at the same time.
commit_list.repo_description: Adds a workflow engine (via ruote) to your Ruby application, with tools for task authorization and locking.

commit_list.message:
Add #tasks query to Bumbleworks::Process

Uses Task::Finder#for_process.  Note that even
though #for_process accepts an actual process
instance, we're sending the wfid directly here. No
need to toss around heavier objects if we don't
need to.
commit_list.repo_description: Adds a workflow engine (via ruote) to your Ruby application, with tools for task authorization and locking.

commit_list.message:
Add task filtering by process

This is significant because it changes the lookup
method used in the Finder class.  Note that we're
now skipping the storage participant and going
straight to the storage, so we can take advantage
of filtering by wfid directly in the storage
query.  An even more significant LoD violation
than before, but given near-future goals, one
I feel okay with for the time being.
commit_list.repo_description: Adds a workflow engine (via ruote) to your Ruby application, with tools for task authorization and locking.
Adds a workflow engine (via ruote) to your Ruby application, with tools for task authorization and locking.

commit_list.message:
Clean up process lookup on entities

Now #processes returns a less surprising result -
an array of actual Bumbleworks::Process instances.
To get the mapping of process names to (possible)
process instances, use #processes_by_name.
commit_list.repo_description: Adds a workflow engine (via ruote) to your Ruby application, with tools for task authorization and locking.

commit_list.message:
Add task finder to Entity module

This allows you to call #tasks on an instance of a Bumbleworks::Entity-
equipped class.  Only tasks from processes launched with this entity
will be returned.  Optionally, a task nickname can be given to filter
the tasks even more (this will most likely return only a single task).
commit_list.repo_description: Adds a workflow engine (via ruote) to your Ruby application, with tools for task authorization and locking.
Adds a workflow engine (via ruote) to your Ruby application, with tools for task authorization and locking.

commit_list.message:
Add Bumbleworks::Entity and ::Process

The former is a module that can be included in your business models to
add methods for launching and investigating processes.  The latter is
a helpful wrapper around processes in Ruote (just as ::Task is a wrapper
for workitems).
commit_list.repo_description: Adds a workflow engine (via ruote) to your Ruby application, with tools for task authorization and locking.
Adds a workflow engine (via ruote) to your Ruby application, with tools for task authorization and locking.

commit_list.message:
Ability to configure options for storage

Added a new configuration setting - 'storage_options' - which defaults
to an empty hash and will be sent as the second argument to the
new_storage method on the adapter.  The base adapter and Hash
adapter (for testing) ignore the options hash completely, but it
can be handy for adapters such as the Redis and Sequel ones.

commit_list.message:
Task::Finder#for_entity works with #id

Instead of requiring entities to respond to #identifier, we fall
back to #id (just as we do on Bumbleworks.launch! when specifying an
entity)
commit_list.repo_description: Adds a workflow engine (via ruote) to your Ruby application, with tools for task authorization and locking.
Adds a workflow engine (via ruote) to your Ruby application, with tools for task authorization and locking.

commit_list.message:
Add Broadcast/Wait for Event expressions to Ruote

Our first custom expressions - these are basically cleaner ways of
setting up a specific type of :tag & await pair.  In vanilla route,
it's a bit of a pain to simply broadcast an event (leave a tag) and
catch that event globally with a :where clause without overwriting
any workitem data in the receiver.  This first iteration can only
compare sent workitem to received workitem, using the "this:" and
"event:" dollar prefixes; later we'll implement sending arbitrary
data with the broadcast that can be assessed in the where clause.
commit_list.repo_description: Adds a workflow engine (via ruote) to your Ruby application, with tools for task authorization and locking.

commit_list.message:
Fix deprecation warning

RSpec doesn't want us to expect a specific error to not be raised.
This actually makes a lot of sense, since something of a false
positive could occur if the method goes wrong in some unexpected way,
raising a different error than the one "not expected" - which would
make the test pass.  What we really care about is that *no* error
is raised.
commit_list.repo_description: Adds a workflow engine (via ruote) to your Ruby application, with tools for task authorization and locking.

commit_list.message:
Set catchall if needed when launching

This allows us to set up a Bumbleworks application with no additional
participants without having to call "register_participants" with no
block (which was nonsensical).
